questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains 1,000 iOS devices and includes Microsoft Intune.

You need to prevent the printing of corporate data from managed apps on the devices.

What should you configure?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Provided answer is correct.

Selected Answer: C
an app protection policy (APP).

Here's why the other options are not ideal:

App configuration policy: This focuses on configuring specific app settings within the app itself, and doesn't offer granular control over data-sharing capabilities like printing.

Security baseline: This defines overall security standards for devices, but doesn't specifically address app-level data protection like printing restrictions.
iOS app provisioning profile: This primarily manages app deployment and doesn't have functionalities for data security measures like printing control.

Using an APP, you can specifically configure the "Block printing" setting to prevent users from printing any corporate data from the managed apps. 

Microsoft documentation on iOS/iPadOS app protection policy settings: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy-settings-ios
Microsoft blog post on using Intune App Protection Policy to protect corporate data: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy

Selected Answer: C
C. an app protection policy

App protection policies apply to iOS devices.

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy#:~:text=Intune%20app%20protection%20policies%20platform%20support%20aligns%20with%20Office%20mobile%20application%20platform%20support%20for%20Android%20and%20iOS/iPadOS%20devices

Selected Answer: C
CORRECT

C- This a setting of App Protection Policy "Printing Org data Select Block to prevent the app from printing work or school data. If you leave this setting to Allow, the default value, users will be able to export and print all Org data."

Selected Answer: C
Correct. App Protection Policy.

Selected Answer: C
App Protection Policy prevents sharing of data outside an application
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policy-settings-ios

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains the users shown in the following table.

//IMG//


In the Microsoft 365 Apps admin center, you create a Microsoft Office customization.

Which users can download the Office customization file from the admin center?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A. Admin3 only.

Explanation:
The ability to download a Microsoft Office customization file from the Microsoft 365 Apps admin center is restricted to users with the Office Apps Administrator role. This role specifically grants permissions to manage Office apps, including customizations.

Why not the other options?
Admin1 (Application Administrator): This role is focused on managing applications registered in Azure AD, not Office app configurations.

Admin2 (Cloud Application Administrator): This role is related to managing cloud app permissions and is not linked to Office apps or customizations.

Admin4 (Security Administrator): This role focuses on security-related tasks and does not have permissions to download Office customization files.

Selected Answer: D
Security Admins don't eve have access to Office 365 Admin Center so rule out Admin 4

Selected Answer: C
The ability to create, modify, or download custom Office deployment configuration files is tied to the Office Apps Administrator role.

- OTHER ROLES DON'T HAVE THAT CAPABILITY

Selected Answer: D
Based on the roles:

Admin1 (Application Administrator): Can both sign in and download Office customization files.
Admin2 (Cloud Application Administrator): Can both sign in and download Office customization files.
Admin3 (Office Apps Administrator): Can both sign in and download Office customization files.
Admin4 (Security Administrator): Cannot sign in or download Office customization files.

comments.content: I was mistaken, Correct answer is C, The Application Administrator role (Admin1) primarily focuses on managing applications within the Microsoft 365 environment, such as configuring app settings, managing app licenses, and deploying apps. However, this role does not include permissions for managing Office customizations or downloading customization files from the Microsoft 365 Apps admin center.

discussion.content:
C

Your Microsoft 365 Apps admin center account must have either the global administrator, security administrator, or Office apps administrator role
C => Correct Answer

Selected Answer: C
Tested this.
To sign into the admin center, your account must have either the global administrator, security administrator, or Office apps administrator role.

Selected Answer: C
I think C as well

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/admincenter/overview#:~:text=Sign%20in%20at%20config.office.com%20with%20your%20admin%20account.%20To%20sign%20into%20the%20admin%20center%2C%20your%20account%20must%20have%20either%20the%20global%20administrator%2C%20security%20administrator%2C%20or%20Office%20apps%20administrator%20role.

comments.content: I think you'd have an issue if your Applications Admin could only configure non Office apps.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct.

How to get to the admin center:

Sign in at config.office.com with your admin account. To sign into the admin center, your account must have either the global administrator, security administrator, or Office apps administrator role.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/admincenter/overview#how-to-get-to-the-admin-center

C. Admin 3 and Admin 4 Only.

How to get to the admin center
Sign in at config.office.com with your admin account. To sign into the admin center, your account must have either the global administrator, security administrator, or Office apps administrator role.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/admincenter/overview

Selected Answer: D
Admin1, Admin2, and Admin3 only.

Here's why:

 Admin1 is an Application Administrator. This role has broad permissions to manage applications in Microsoft 365, including downloading customization files.
 Admin2 is a Cloud Application Administrator. While this role primarily focuses on cloud-based applications, it still grants access to managing desktop applications like Office and downloading related customization files.
 Admin3 is an Office Apps Administrator. This role is specifically responsible for managing Office applications and has direct access to download customization files.
 Admin4 is a Security Administrator. This role deals with security settings and policies and doesn't have the specific permissions required to download customization files.

Therefore, only Admin1, Admin2, and Admin3 have the necessary roles to download the Office customization file from the admin center.
Chatgpt answer is C

Selected Answer: C
C IS CORRECT

Selected Answer: C
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/admincenter/overview

To sign into the admin center, your account must have either the global administrator, security administrator, or Office apps administrator role.

Selected Answer: C
Its C.
- The Application Administrator role in Microsoft 365 primarily focuses on managing and configuring applications within the Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) and does not have direct access to the Microsoft 365 Apps Admin Center.

- While the Cloud Application Administrator role has permissions related to application management, it may not provide direct access to the Microsoft 365 Apps Admin Center. 
- While the Security Administrator role is focused on managing security aspects, it may not provide direct access to the Microsoft 365 Apps Admin Center.

Selected Answer: C
Its C
To sign into the admin center, your account must have either the global administrator, security administrator, or Office apps administrator role.

Selected Answer: C
To sign into the admin center, your account must have either the global administrator, security administrator, or Office apps administrator role.

Admin 3 & Admin 4.

Sign in at config.office.com with your admin account. To sign into the admin center, your account must have either the global administrator, security administrator, or Office apps administrator role.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/admincenter/overview#how-to-get-to-the-admin-center

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.

You need to download a report that lists all the devices that are NOT enrolled in Microsoft Intune and are assigned an app protection policy.

What should you select in the Microsoft Intune admin center?

choices.B: Apps, and then App protection policies

discussion.content: I can confirm it is D. I could not check that in my dummy tenant as I have no devices so asked my husband to check his production Intune and under Apps\Monitor\App Protection status, there is a column Management Type and there it tells you "managed" or "unmanaged" which was the key to the question to check if the device is enrolled or not

comments.content: Management type column under Apps>Monitor>App Protection Status shows the "All App types" the ones you have selected to be protected in the user's device. It doesn't show "managed" or "unmanaged".

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Option D (Apps, and then Monitor) might seem like a logical choice, but it doesn’t provide the specific report needed here. To identify devices not enrolled in Microsoft Intune but assigned an app protection policy, you should go to Apps > App protection policies in the Intune admin center (Option B). From there, you can access detailed reports that show information about such devices.

Selected Answer: B
App Protection Policies (APPs):
APPs are used to protect company data on devices that are managed and unmanaged.
Reports about app protection policies typically focus on devices where these policies are applied, including unmanaged ones.

Selected Answer: D
In Intune go to Apps > Monitor > App Protection Status. There you will find a column with the name "Management type". You can download an export file.
D. Apps > Monitor > App Protection Status

Devil is in the details: You need to download a report that lists all the devices that are NOT enrolled in Microsoft Intune and are assigned an app protection policy.

Only in Monitor you can use a filter. So it is D.

Selected Answer: D
Apps > Monitor > App Protection Status

D. Apps, and then Monitor.

This option allows you to monitor apps, including app protection policies. By selecting "Monitor" under the "Apps" section, you can access insights and reports related to app protection policies, which should include information about devices that are assigned these policies but are not enrolled in Intune.

Selected Answer: D
D is still correct from APPS then MONITOR then APP PROTECTION STATUS you can filter for "unmanaged" devices and see al the unmanaged decices that have a policy assigned

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policies-monitor#:~:text=App%20Protection%20Status%3A%20The%20app%20is%20considered%20protected%20if%20it%20is%20targeted%20with%20a%20MAM%20policy.

Selected Answer: D
d is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D, Apps and Monitor section. "App Protection Status' monitor will show the Management Type as "Unmanaged" and you can come to the list using unmanaged filter.
ChatGPT answer is C.

Selected Answer: D
D. Apps, and then Monitor

You can check if an App Protection policy is assigned and verify if a device is enrolled in Intune. It's the only option that can confirm both on a single dashboard. You need to modify the columns but that's expected if you're looking for a granular report such as this.

Selected Answer: D
Apps\Monitor\App Protection status, there are a lot of info. Checked in my prod environment.

Selected Answer: D
View the App protection status report
Sign in to the Microsoft Intune admin center.
Select Apps > Monitor > App protection status.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policies-monitor

Selected Answer: D
D IS CORRECT? TESTED ON MY TENANT
Agreed with BJS78, Go check for u self Apps -> monitor -> App Protection status
For me it's C

comments.content: No. Devices then monitor only gives you the devices enrolled in Intune. Not the devices that aren't.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
To download a report of devices not enrolled in Microsoft Intune assigned app protection policy, you should select Reports, and then Device compliance. Here are the steps you can follow:

Sign in to the Microsoft Intune admin center.
Select Reports > Device compliance > Reports tab > Devices without compliance policy.
Select Generate report.

If you check Apps ¦ Monitor, you can select "App Protection status". There you can see if the device is managed or not (enrolled or not to Intune) and also the MDM ID. If no ID, not enrolled to Intune --> Selected Answer: D.
In the App protection section you can see only what apps and how many check-ins your policy generate. Nothing more.

Selected Answer: B
I would go with B: Apps, and then App protection policies

Selected Answer: B
ChatGPT went with B. 
Go to the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center.
Navigate to Apps > App protection policies.
Review the policies assigned and take note of their details.

Selected Answer: A
Option A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/reports
C- https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/microsoft/view/74720-exam-md-101-topic-5-question-23-discussion/

Selected Answer: C
The options **B. Apps, and then App protection policies** and **D. Apps, and then Monitor** in the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center are not the correct choices for the following reasons:

- **B. Apps, and then App protection policies**: This section is used to create, configure, and assign app protection policies. It does not provide a report of devices that are not enrolled in Intune.

- **A. Apps, and then Monitor**: This section provides monitoring and analytics for your apps. It does not provide a report of devices that are not enrolled in Intune.

The **C Devices > Monitor** section provides various reports related to device enrollment. Therefore, it is the correct choice for downloading a report that lists all the devices that are NOT enrolled in Microsoft Intune.

Selected Answer: C
Option C

Selected Answer: B
B it is.
Apps>App protection policies and then click on App protection report: WIP via MDM. That option is next to Export on the same banner of Create policy, towards the right side.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 tenant that contains the objects shown in the following table.

//IMG//


In the Microsoft Intune admin center, you are creating a Microsoft 365 Apps app named App1.

To which objects can you assign App1?

choices.E: Admin1, Group1, Group2, Group3, and Group4
choices.D: Group1, Group2, Group3, and Group4 only

discussion.content: group4 is the security group i guess ?

Selected Answer: C
group 4 is a security group, this is a mistake
for exclusion I say C
because, I'm sure that you can assign an app to a M365 Group, so, only C, D or E . I'm sure that you cannot assign a app to a distribution list too, so this excludes D and E . C is the last one. ;)

Selected Answer: C
C is closest true answer. In the Microsoft Intune admin center, you can assign an MS 365 Apps app to: Users (including Admins), Microsoft 365 Groups, Security Groups
and Mail-enabled Security Groups
However, you cannot assign apps directly to Distribution Groups.

Selected Answer: C

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/app-protection-policies#target-app-protection-policies-based-on-device-management-state

comments.content: Policy1 is an app protection policy targeting all device types, including unmanaged devices. For Android devices, the Company Portal app is required alongside Microsoft 365 apps to enforce app protection policies. The policy is assigned to users, not devices, as app protection policies target user identities and can apply to both enrolled and non-enrolled devices..

discussion.content:

App Protection Policies only target users so answer for 2nd is users only.

Box 2: Users Only
